intro: Rhynchospora glauca var. ustilaginosa, commonly known as the glaucous moorgrass, is a variant of the moorgrass species native to wetland and marshy environments in North America. It is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and small, spike-like inflorescences that produce tiny, white to pale blue flowers. The plant typically grows in nutrient-poor soils and is often found in bogs, fens, and other moist habitats. Its botanical features include a rhizomatous growth habit and a preference for acidic conditions. This variant is of interest in ecological studies due to its role in wetland ecosystems and its sensitivity to environmental changes.
